3. 1/3 or more of board members are defined as independent in accordance with international best practices. 
4. Board diversity, including but not limited to gender, achieved in all aspects. 
5. Roles of chair and CEO are separate. Board chair is independent, or a lead independent director has been designated.
Committees
6. Majority of audit Committee membership is independent. 
7. Other specialized committees of the board exist to address special technical topics or potential conflicts of interest (e.g., nominations and compensation).
8. Committee of independent directors approves all material related-party transactions.
Meeting Frequency and Credit Decisions
9. Non-executive directors meet separately at least once a year. 
10. The institution has an independent asset (or loan) review function reporting directly to the board (or a committee of the board) to ensure timely recognition and resolution of impaired assets.
Evaluation and Performance
11. Board, committees and individual directors undergo an annual evaluation.
Oversight of E&S
12. Strategy and risk appetite integrate E&S issues/risks. 
13. In institutions involved in high E&S risk transactions/lending, at least one director or more has in-depth knowledge of E&S risks. 
14. ESG issues are recurring board agenda items; board approves ESG strategy and E&S policies; routinely reviews E&S performance; and ensures effectiveness of External Communications Mechanism (ECM).

faqs.question: Leadership
faqs.answer:
Composition
1. 1/2 or more of board members are defined as independent in accordance with interna tional best practices.
Committees
2. Audit committee membership 100% independent. 
3. Special board-level CG committee established. 
4. Specialized committees (governance, nominations, E&S/sustainability, and compensation) composed of a majority of independent directors, including the chair. 
5. Compensation committee ensures that executive compensation is based on performance and long-term incentives (and adjusted for all types of current and future risk), based on financial and non-financial performance.
Meeting Frequency and Credit Decisions
6. Independent directors periodically meet separately.
Evaluation and Performance
7. Board and committee evaluations conducted/facilitated by a third party.
Oversight of E&S
8. Board reviews independent audits on effectiveness of Environment and Social Management System (ESMS). 
9. Board ensures appropriate dialogue between the institution and key stakeholders.

sidebar.category: C - Control Environment and Processes: Internal Control (IC), Internal Audit (IA), External Audit (EA), Compliance Function, Risk Management

faqs.question: Basic Practices
faqs.answer:
Internal Controls
1. Institution has established documented internal control policies and procedures. 
2. The institution’s policies and practices with respect to reporting regulatory capital, portfolio quality and performance, anti-money laundering and all other matters of regulatory compliance meet all standards established by the corresponding national regulator(s).
Internal Audit
3. Internal audit function regularly interfaces with external auditors and is accountable to the board.
Risk Governance
4. Board approves risk appetite and ensures its alignment with the bank’s strategic, capital and financial plans and compensation practices. 
5. Institution has established risk-management framework with a chief risk officer (CRO) or equivalent with unfettered access to the board.
Compliance and AML/CFT
6. Designated compliance officer (CCO). 
7. Established compliance policy. 
8. Designated AML/CFT function is in place. 
9. Whistleblowing policy established.
External Audit
10. Written Management Letters provided by external auditor.
Integrating of E&S
11. Institution addresses compliance with E&S law and regulations. in its operations/lending transactions.
Subsidiary Governance
12. Institution can identify its subsidiaries.

faqs.question: Intermediate Practices
faqs.answer:
Internal Controls
1. “Three lines of defense” model of risk management, internal control and internal audit has been adopted.
2. Audit committee ensures corrective actions on control deficiencies identified in Management Letters.
Internal Audit
3. Internal audit function is independent, objective, risk-based, and has unlimited scope of activity. 
4. Head of internal audit reports to the audit committee and administratively to management.
Risk Governance
5. Board routinely monitors risk management and compliance with policies and procedures. 
6. CRO reports to board-level risk management committee or equivalent. 
7. The full board receives annual reviews, with input from outside sources of expertise, of the institution’s risk management (credit, market and operational risk) system.
Compliance and AML/CFT
8. Board approves compliance policy, ensures independence of the compliance function and assesses its effectiveness. 
9. Comprehensive compliance program annually reviewed, with mechanisms to report wrongdoing and misconduct. 
10. CCO reports to the audit committee or equivalent and administratively to management. 
11. Board oversees the integrity, independence and effectiveness of the entity’s policies and procedures for whistleblowing.
Subsidiary Governance
12. Institution has policies and procedures to control the creation and dissolution of subsidiaries.

faqs.question: Good International Practices
faqs.answer:
Risk Governance
1. An effective risk governance framework includes a strong risk culture, a well- developed risk appetite articulated through the Risk Appetite Statement, and well-defined responsibilities for risk management in particular and control functions in general.
External Audit
2. Audit committee owns relationship with external auditor (EA); agrees on scope and audit fees, and undertakes a periodic quality assessment of EA, using relevant Audit Quality Indicators.
Integrating of E&S
3. Periodic ESG, IT, and Information Security internal audits. 
4. Comprehensive ESMS integrated in risk-management framework, and E&S risks are part of establishing the risk appetite. 
5. E&S/sustainability head has unfettered access to senior management and CRO.
Subsidiary Governance
6. Institution has a centralized subsidiary governance function and subsidiaries are categorized based on complexity and an appropriate governance framework applied to each category.

faqs.question: Leadership
faqs.answer:
Internal Controls
1. Control environment in accordance with highest international standards, including but not limited to IIA,5 COSO, ISO 31000, 19600, 37001, and 27001. 2. The organizational structure adopted by management has a positive effect on performance, productivity, and leadership effectiveness.
Internal Audit
3. Internal audit function is in line with best international standards and guidelines, such as the Basel Committee Internal Audit Function in Banks. 
4. Audit committee ensures that the internal audit function is subject to periodic quality assessment by third party.
Risk Governance
5. Risk governance frame-work includes robust communication within the institution about risk, both across the institution and through reporting to the board and senior management. 
6. The board ensures that the institution follows highest international standards on risk management (such as those of Basel Committee on Banking Supervision on credit risk, operational risk and other risks).
Compliance and AML/CFT
7. Institution’s AML/CFT policies and practices are in line with best international standards (such as FATF Standards and Basel Committee on Banking Supervision 2017 Guidelines on “Sound management of risks related to money laundering and financing of terrorism”). 
8. Compliance function is in line with international standards, such as ISO 19700.
External Audit
9. Audit committee reviews long association of EA.
Integrating of E&S
10. Board or sustainability committee ensures corrective actions on E&S issues. 
11. Head of ESG reports to board E&S/ sustainability committee.
Subsidiary Governance
12. Board exercises oversight over the organizational structure and the activities of its subsidiaries.

6. Designated compliance officer (CCO). 
7. Established compliance policy. 
8. Designated AML/CFT function is in place. 
9. Whistleblowing policy established.
External Audit
10. Written Management Letters provided by external auditor.
Integrating of E&S
11. Institution addresses compliance with E&S law and regulations. in its operations/lending transactions.
Subsidiary Governance
12. Institution can identify its subsidiaries.

faqs.question: Intermediate Practices
faqs.answer:
Internal Controls
1. “Three lines of defense” model of risk management, internal control and internal audit has been adopted.
2. Audit committee ensures corrective actions on control deficiencies identified in Management Letters.
Internal Audit
3. Internal audit function is independent, objective, risk-based, and has unlimited scope of activity. 
4. Head of internal audit reports to the audit committee and administratively to management.
Risk Governance
5. Board routinely monitors risk management and compliance with policies and procedures. 
6. CRO reports to board-level risk management committee or equivalent. 
7. The full board receives annual reviews, with input from outside sources of expertise, of the institution’s risk management (credit, market and operational risk) system.
Compliance and AML/CFT
8. Board approves compliance policy, ensures independence of the compliance function and assesses its effectiveness. 
9. Comprehensive compliance program annually reviewed, with mechanisms to report wrongdoing and misconduct. 
10. CCO reports to the audit committee or equivalent and administratively to management. 
11. Board oversees the integrity, independence and effectiveness of the entity’s policies and procedures for whistleblowing.
Subsidiary Governance
12. Institution has policies and procedures to control the creation and dissolution of subsidiaries.

faqs.question: Good International Practices
faqs.answer:
Risk Governance
1. An effective risk governance framework includes a strong risk culture, a well- developed risk appetite articulated through the Risk Appetite Statement, and well-defined responsibilities for risk management in particular and control functions in general.
External Audit
2. Audit committee owns relationship with external auditor (EA); agrees on scope and audit fees, and undertakes a periodic quality assessment of EA, using relevant Audit Quality Indicators.
Integrating of E&S
3. Periodic ESG, IT, and Information Security internal audits. 
4. Comprehensive ESMS integrated in risk-management framework, and E&S risks are part of establishing the risk appetite. 
5. E&S/sustainability head has unfettered access to senior management and CRO.
Subsidiary Governance
6. Institution has a centralized subsidiary governance function and subsidiaries are categorized based on complexity and an appropriate governance framework applied to each category.

faqs.question: Leadership
faqs.answer:
Internal Controls
1. Control environment in accordance with highest international standards, including but not limited to IIA,5 COSO, ISO 31000, 19600, 37001, and 27001. 2. The organizational structure adopted by management has a positive effect on performance, productivity, and leadership effectiveness.
Internal Audit
3. Internal audit function is in line with best international standards and guidelines, such as the Basel Committee Internal Audit Function in Banks. 
4. Audit committee ensures that the internal audit function is subject to periodic quality assessment by third party.
Risk Governance
5. Risk governance frame-work includes robust communication within the institution about risk, both across the institution and through reporting to the board and senior management. 
6. The board ensures that the institution follows highest international standards on risk management (such as those of Basel Committee on Banking Supervision on credit risk, operational risk and other risks).
Compliance and AML/CFT
7. Institution’s AML/CFT policies and practices are in line with best international standards (such as FATF Standards and Basel Committee on Banking Supervision 2017 Guidelines on “Sound management of risks related to money laundering and financing of terrorism”). 
8. Compliance function is in line with international standards, such as ISO 19700.
External Audit
9. Audit committee reviews long association of EA.
Integrating of E&S
10. Board or sustainability committee ensures corrective actions on E&S issues. 
11. Head of ESG reports to board E&S/ sustainability committee.
Subsidiary Governance
12. Board exercises oversight over the organizational structure and the activities of its subsidiaries.

faqs.question: Basic Practices
faqs.answer:
Financial Reporting
1. Financial statements are audited by recognized independent external auditing firm.
ESG Disclosure
2. ESG/sustainability reporting, if any, follows minimum national requirement.

faqs.question: Intermediate Practices
faqs.answer:
Financial Reporting
1. Financial statements prepared in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) and/or jurisdictional standards. 
2. Financial statements are audited in accordance with International Standards on Auditing (ISA). 
3. Audit committee oversees financial and nonfinancial reporting and audit.
Risk Appetite
4. The institution discloses its key risks, including credit.
Corporate Disclosure
5. Institution discloses its code of ethics/ conduct.

faqs.question: Good International Practices
faqs.answer:
Financial Reporting
1. Disclosure policy in place.
Risk Appetite
2. Institution discloses its risk appetite.
Corporate Disclosure
3. Shareholders provided with accurate and timely information on the number of shares of all classes held by controlling shareholders and their affiliates (ownership concentration).
ESG Disclosure
4. Annual report includes ESG information. 
5. Institution discloses aggregate E&S risk exposure in its portfolio.

faqs.question: Leadership
faqs.answer:
Risk Appetite
1. Risk appetite disclosure includes both qualitative and quantitative information.
Corporate Disclosure
2. Tax transparency statement disclosed. 
3. Executive compensation is disclosed. 
4. Dividend policy is disclosed. 
5. Significant ultimate beneficial shareholders are disclosed.
ESG Disclosure
6. Nonfinancial disclosure in accordance with highest international standards (e.g., GRI, IIRC, SASB). 
7. Periodic nonfinancial reporting of ESG issues that are of concern to stakeholders. 
8. ESG data subject to an annual audit by an independent provider.

faqs.question: Basic Practices
faqs.answer:
Voting Rights
1. All shareholders of the same class have equal voting, subscription, and transfer rights. 
2. Minority shareholders receive adequate notice and the agenda for all shareholders’ meetings; and are permitted to participate and vote at shareholders’ meetings.
Protective Rights
3. Holders of all securities of the same type and class have access to equal information (fair disclosure). 
4. The institution has policy on related-party lending and approval procedures.

faqs.question: Intermediate Practices
faqs.answer:
Voting Rights
1. Effective representation of minority shareholders through cumulative voting or similar mechanisms; and economic rights such as inspection rights, exit rights, and tag-along rights. 
2. Institution has a dividend policy. 
3. Clearly articulated and enforced policies on treatment of minority shareholders in changes of control.
Protective Rights
4. Well-understood policy and practice of full and timely disclosure to shareholders of all material related-party lending and other transactions. 
5. The board takes into account the legitimate interests of depositors (policy-holders, for insurance companies), shareholders and other relevant stakeholders.

faqs.question: Good International Practices
faqs.answer:
Voting Rights
1. Effective shareholder voting mechanisms to protect minority shareholders from concentrated ownership or strong conflicts of interest with controlling shareholders (e.g., supermajority or “majority of minority” provisions). 
2. Shareholders are consulted on executive compensation.
Protective Rights
3. Well-understood policy and practices of institution material transactions that could potentially affect the rights of minority shareholders. 
4. Annual report discloses material risks to minority shareholders associated with controlling shareholders, ownership concentration, cross-holdings, and voting-power imbalances. 
5. The board ensures that the institution maintains an effective relationship with its supervisors.

faqs.question: Leadership
faqs.answer:
Voting Rights
1. Treatment of shareholders consistent with best international market practices. 
2. Executive compensation subject to shareholder approval. 
3. Each share is afforded one vote at the AGM.
Protective Rights
4. Related-party transactions (over 2.5% of net assets or $150,000) subject to shareholder approval or stricter requirements.

faqs.question: Basic Practices
faqs.answer:
External Communication Mechanism
1. Institution addresses compliance with E&S law and regulations for stakeholder engagement.

faqs.question: Intermediate Practices
faqs.answer:
External Communication Mechanism
1. Institution has assigned responsibility to review external E&S communications.

faqs.question: Good International Practices
faqs.answer:
External Communication Mechanism
1. Institution has a dedicated external communications mechanism to (a) receive and register external communications from the public; (b) screen and assess the issues raised and determine how to address them; (c) provide, track, and document responses, if any; and (d) adjust its management systems, as appropriate. 
2. There is a written procedure outlining how external E&S communications are handled. 
3. Institution keeps track of communications by type and severity/risk. 
4. External E&S inquiries are reported to senior management and Board.

faqs.question: Leadership
faqs.answer:
External Communication Mechanism
1. Institution pro-actively seeks to meet with stakeholders to solicit and discuss feedback about its policies and procedures as well as concerns about companies/projects that they may have financed.

questions.question: Do you have a formal Human Rights policy approved by your board or equivalent governing body?
Is your Human Rights policy a standalone document or part of a broader code of conduct or sustainability policy?
Does the policy explicitly reference internationally recognized human rights standards (e.g., UDHR, ILO Core Conventions, UNGPs)?
What human rights commitments are included in your policy?
Is the policy available publicly?
Who is the policy applicable to?
How is the policy communicated internally?
How is the policy communicated externally (e.g., to suppliers or partners)?
Has your company identified key internal and external stakeholders for engagement on human rights topics?
Did you engage internal or external human rights experts during the development of your policy?
Was there stakeholder consultation involved in policy development (e.g., employees, unions, community groups)?
How frequently is your human rights policy reviewed or updated?
Are the human rights commitments reflected in the following operational areas?
Do you provide training to employees on human rights and ethical conduct?
Is there a grievance mechanism or whistleblower process for reporting human rights violations?
How does your company monitor compliance with human rights policies?
Do you publish a human rights or sustainability report?
Have you ever identified actual or potential human rights impacts in your operations or supply chain?
What actions have you taken in response to identified risks or violations?
Does your organization align with any human rights frameworks or certifications (e.g., UNGPs, SA8000, B Corp, ISO 26000)?
Name of the person responsible for human rights within the company:
Do you wish to integrate automated alerts or tracking for high-risk regions or suppliers?
Has your company conducted a formal human rights impact assessment (HRIA)?
At what intervals are human rights risks and impacts assessed?
